newsitem.title: THAILAND: New Thai insurance licences seen finalised in Q1.
newsitem.headline: New Thai insurance licences seen finalised in Q1.

text.p: Thai Commerce Minister Narongchai Akrasanee said on Wednesday the government would likely finalise decisions on new Thai insurance licences within the first quarter of 1997.

Narongchai told foreign businessmen at a chamber of commerce function a nine-member committee would soon make the long-awaited decisions which had been repeatedly delayed during the two previous Thai governments.
He said the committee would include five people from the private sector, who would make transparent decisions to avoid charges of unfair lobbying.
"They are honest people. There is no need for lobbying or (applicants) preparing to make special donations," he said.
The remainder of the committee would consist of members of the Commerce Ministry.

Thailand's previous government last year picked 66 new life and non-life licence bidders out of 87 applicants but the then coalition government of Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa was dissolved before the licences were issued.
The 66 bidders included 35 who applied for life insurance business and 31 seeking non-life insurance licences.
Narongchai told reporters earlier on Wednesday that the panel may either call a new round of bidding or review the previous 66 winners.

Industry sources have mostly viewed the number of accepted applicants as too high. They said a decision to license all of them would have a significant impact on the 101 billion baht ($4.0 billion) Thai insurance market which grew 20 percent in 1995.
